column7: description_check

column5: Check for abnormal noise and vibration
column7: Listen for rubbing/grinding; check vibration levels.
Hand-feel or monitor gauges (must be within OEM limits).
Inspect seal area and gaskets for excessive fluid leakage.
Verify level (sight glass); check for water contamination/foaming.
Clean off dirt/debris to ensure proper cooling.
Visually inspect anchor and hold-down bolts for looseness.
Rotate shaft several turns by hand to coat bearings.
Apply specified amount/type of grease.
Visually check coupling bolts for looseness or wear.
Use a dial indicator/laser to check pump-to-motor alignment.
Detailed analysis to identify unbalance or bearing defects.
Drain old oil completely and refill with specified new oil.
Measure axial and radial clearance (play).
Apply rust-preventive coating during shutdown.
Disassemble for comprehensive inspection of internals.
Check for erosion, corrosion, or pitting damage.
Verify straightness and measure runout against tolerance.
Investigate and document the failure cause.
Verify oil level; check working pressure and temperature.
Check pressure drop indicator for blockage.
Release accumulated condensation.
Clean air/oil cooler surfaces.
Inspect and adjust belt tension (if applicable).

column5: Clean or replace air filter element
column7: Remove/replace the primary air filter element.
Test relief valve functionality.
Complete oil and oil filter change.
Replace the element to maintain air quality.
Verify the oil level is correct.
Listen for noise or excessive vibration.
Inspect and adjust belt tension and sheave condition.
Verify blades are set to the correct pitch/angle.
Lubricate motor and fan shaft bearings as specified.
Drain and refill the gear reducer oil.
Inspect tightness of bolts on fan blades, hub, and gearbox mounts.
Verify oil level.
Check amperage against nameplate/baseline.
Inspect for leakage indicating seal wear.
Ensure motor and gearbox foundation bolts are secure.
Verify alignment between motor and gearbox shafts.
Drain, clean housing, and refill with new oil.
Check blades for cracks, corrosion, or signs of impact damage.
Verify belt is running centered on rollers/pulleys.
Ensure belt cleaners are functioning and material isn't piling up.
Check for rollers that are seized or making excessive noise.
Verify oil level in the conveyor drive gearbox.
Check and adjust the belt tensioning system (take-up).
Disassemble, clean, inspect, and re-grease/replace pulley bearings.
Listen for rubbing/grinding; check vibration levels by hand or meter.
Monitor temperature (hand-feel or gauge) and compare to baseline/limits.
Observe the rate of leakage; ensure it's within acceptable limits for the seal type.
Verify oil level is at the sight glass midpoint or specified mark.
Visually inspect all coupling bolts for tightness.
Wipe down surfaces, remove debris, and ensure cooling fins are clear.

column5: Top up grease in re-greasable bearings
column7: Apply the manufacturer-specified amount of grease to motor and pump bearings.
Verify all anchor bolts holding the motor and pump base are tight.
Record operating pressure readings and compare against normal operating range.
Conduct a detailed analysis to diagnose issues (unbalance, misalignment, bearing defects).
Use laser/dial indicators to verify pump and motor shaft alignment.
Drain old oil, inspect drained oil for contamination, and refill with new specified oil.
Measure axial and radial shaft clearance (play).
If accessible (via a short shutdown), inspect seal faces for scoring or seats for pitting.
Shut down, remove rotating assembly, and inspect for erosion, corrosion, or cavitation damage.
Check for wear marks, pitting, or corrosion, especially near seal areas.
Measure flow rate (Q) and head (H) to calculate efficiency.
Investigate the exact cause of failure (e.g., seal failure due to dry run, bearing failure due to contamination).
Replace seal, bearings, or shaft, ensuring all new parts meet OEM specs.
Reinstall components, perform final alignment check, and run a monitored start-up test.
Inspect seals (shaft, flange) for excessive product dusting or spillage.
Listen for grinding or knocking sounds; check vibration levels.
Verify the lubrication oil level is correct via the sight glass.
Record amperage and compare against baseline or nameplate rating.
Check tension of the chain or V-belts (if applicable).
Remove product buildup and dust from the feeder and motor body.
Inspect coupling guard for rubbing; visually check coupling bolts.
If inspection ports are available, check for material dragging or contact.
Drain old oil completely and refill with the correct, specified oil grade.
Apply the specified amount and type of grease to accessible bearings.
Torque check the bolts securing the housing and end plates.
Verify that the air purge system (if equipped) is maintaining positive pressure at the seals.
Disassemble the unit to inspect the rotor vanes, housing interior, and end plates.

column5: Inspect and replace worn rotor tips
column7: Replace flexible or adjustable rotor tips/vanes if wear exceeds tolerance.
Replace or service the shaft seals (e.g., packing or lip seals).
Safely isolate and clear blockages; inspect for damage caused by foreign objects.
Replace damaged or sheared vanes/tips.

column5: Check for abnormal noise and vibration
column7: Listen for grinding, clicking, or excessive rattling indicating chain tension or wear issues.
Visually check chain sag and measure wear at a consistent point.
Observe the consistency of material flow and check for excessive dust or leakage from seals.
Check the condition of the bottom and side wear liners for deep scoring or exposure of the casing.

column5: Clean exterior and remove material buildup
column7: Remove any piled-up material from the casing, particularly near the drive and tail sections.
Verify the oil level is correct via the sight glass.
Check the motor-to-gearbox coupling for wear or misalignment.

column5: Check and tighten all bolted connections
column7: Torque check bolts on the gearbox, motor mount, and casing flanges.
Drain old oil completely and refill with the correct, specified oil grade.
Check the drag chain flights for bends, breakage, or excessive wear against the casing.
Apply the specified amount and type of grease to accessible bearings.

column5: Overhaul and inspect tail and head shaft assemblies
column7: Disassemble and inspect bearings, shaft runout, and sprocket tooth wear.
Perform a comprehensive measurement of the entire chain length for stretch/elongation.

column5: Clear jam and inspect component integrity
column7: Safely isolate and remove jammed material; inspect flights, chain, and sprockets for damage.
Replace any broken links, pins, or flights.
Visually inspect the pump head, tubing, injection points, and connections for any signs of chemical seepage.
Confirm the pump's output and pressure are stable and match the required dosage setting.
Verify the oil level is correct via the sight glass (for hydraulically actuated pumps).

column5: Inspect and clean chemical strainer/foot valve
column7: Check the strainer for blockages and ensure the foot valve seats correctly.
Inspect tubing for brittleness, cracking, or signs of chemical attack.
Inspect the coupling (if external) for any signs of wear or misalignment.
Check and tighten all bolts securing the pump to its base or skid.
Verify the stroke setting corresponds accurately to the actual measured output volume.

column5: Change or top up gear oil
column7: Drain and refill the oil (or top up) with the specified grade.
Disassemble and clean or replace the spring and ball/seat assemblies.
Inspect the diaphragm for ballooning, cracks, or signs of chemical degradation.
Disassemble the liquid end completely, clean all parts, and replace all soft goods (O-rings, gaskets, packing).
Check for excessive backlash or wear on gear teeth and linkages.
Safely isolate and contain the chemical leak according to site safety protocol.
Replace the diaphragm or plunger assembly, along with all associated seals and O-rings.

column5: Check for abnormal noise and vibration
column7: Listen for grinding or bearing noise; check vibration levels (hand-feel or meter).
Check temperature gauges or use an infrared thermometer.
Ensure all guards are securely in place and not rubbing.

column5: Check belt tension and wear (if applicable)
column7: Inspect V-belts for cracks and ensure tension is within the specified range.
Remove accumulated dust and debris from the motor and fan casing.
Torque check all mounting bolts for the fan, motor, and pedestals.
Apply the specified amount and type of grease to accessible motor and fan bearings.
Conduct a spectral analysis to diagnose unbalance, misalignment, or bearing defects.
Use laser/dial indicators to verify alignment between the motor and fan shafts.
Check sheaves/pulleys for groove wear and buildup.
Inspect the blades for material buildup, erosion, or corrosion.
Check linkages and actuators for free movement and tightness.
Inspect the fan shaft, housing interior, and scroll for structural damage or significant wear.
Change oil (if applicable) or thoroughly inspect bearing condition.
Balance the fan wheel in place after cleaning or internal maintenance.
Investigate the cause of failure (e.g., failed bearing due to contamination, blade fracture).
Replace the damaged impeller, shaft, or housing section.
Check bearing oil/metal temperature (RTDs or gauges) and compare to baseline/limits.
Check overall vibration levels and compare to alarm limits.
Verify oil level is correct; check for leaks, froth, or discoloration.
Verify flow rate and temperature differential across the oil cooler.
Visually check coupling bolts for tightness and inspect the coupling guard.
Remove any accumulated coal dust or debris from the fan casing and motor body.
Torque check all anchor and mounting bolts for the fan, motor, and pedestals.
Verify the oil pump pressure is stable and within the operating range.
Conduct a spectral analysis to diagnose unbalance, misalignment, or bearing wear.
Check belts for cracks, tension, and check sheaves/pulleys for groove wear.
Shut down and physically inspect the blades for erosion, pitting, or material buildup.
Check all linkages, pins, and actuators for free movement and lubricant.
Use laser or dial indicators to verify and correct alignment between the motor and fan shafts.
Major shutdown inspection of internal components, including casing wear liners.
Balance the fan wheel in place after any cleaning, repair, or internal inspection.
Replace or repair the damaged component.
Investigate the cause of failure (e.g., failed bearing due to inadequate cooling, high vibration overload).
Check bearing oil/metal temperature (RTDs or gauges) and compare to baseline/limits.
Check overall vibration levels and compare to alarm limits.
Verify oil level is correct; check for leaks, froth, or discoloration.
Verify flow rate and temperature differential across the oil cooler.
Visually check coupling bolts for tightness and inspect the coupling guard.
Remove any accumulated coal dust or debris from the fan casing and motor body.
Torque check all anchor and mounting bolts for the fan, motor, and pedestals.
Verify the oil pump pressure is stable and within the operating range.
Conduct a spectral analysis to diagnose unbalance, misalignment, or bearing wear.
Check belts for cracks, tension, and check sheaves/pulleys for groove wear.
Shut down and physically inspect the blades for erosion, pitting, or material buildup.
Check all linkages, pins, and actuators for free movement and lubricant.
Use laser or dial indicators to verify and correct alignment between the motor and fan shafts.
Major shutdown inspection of internal components, including casing wear liners.
Balance the fan wheel in place after any cleaning, repair, or internal inspection.
Replace or repair the damaged component.
Investigate the cause of failure (e.g., failed bearing due to inadequate cooling, high vibration overload).
Check the air discharge temperature against the baseline or maximum limit.
Verify the lubrication oil level in both the gear end and drive end sumps.

column5: Check for abnormal noise and vibration
column7: Listen for knocking, clicking, or rubbing sounds; check vibration levels.
Remove and clean or replace the air intake filter element.

column5: Inspect V-belt tension and wear (if applicable)
column7: Check belts for cracks and ensure tension is within the specified range.
Bump-check the pressure relief valve to ensure it's functioning and set correctly.
Record running amperage and compare against the nameplate rating and baseline.
Torque check all anchor and mounting bolts for the blower and motor.
Conduct a spectral analysis to diagnose bearing defects or rotor imbalance.
Drain old oil completely from both sumps and refill with new, specified oil.
Inspect timing gears for wear and check the lobe clearance (timing) using feeler gauges.
Check oil seals for leakage and air seals (e.g., labyrinth seals) for damage or material carryover.
Disassemble the unit to inspect lobes for rubbing marks, corrosion, or wear.
Use laser/dial indicators to verify and correct alignment between the motor and blower shafts.
Investigate the cause of failure (e.g., bearing failure from timing, overheating from clogged filter).
Replace all damaged bearings and associated seals.
Listen for rubbing/grinding; check vibration levels by hand or meter.
Monitor temperature (hand-feel or gauge); compare to baseline/limits.
Observe leakage rate; ensure it's within acceptable limits for seal type.
Verify oil level is at sight glass midpoint or specified mark.
Visually inspect all coupling bolts for tightness.
Wipe down surfaces, remove debris, ensure cooling fins are clear.
Apply manufacturer-specified grease to motor and pump bearings.
Verify anchor bolts holding motor/pump base are tight.
Record operating pressure; compare to normal operating range.
Diagnose issues: unbalance, misalignment, bearing defects.
Use laser/dial indicators for shaft alignment.
Drain old oil, inspect for contamination, refill with new oil.
Measure axial/radial shaft clearance (play).
Check for scoring, pitting during short shutdown.

Measure flow rate (Q) and head (H) to check efficiency.
Diagnose exact cause of failure (e.g., seal dry-run, bearing contamination).
Replace seal, bearings, shaft—ensure new parts meet OEM specs.
Reinstall, align, and run a monitored start-up test.
Listen for any unusual sounds or vibrations in the oil pump/motor assembly.
Confirm oil level is within the marked safe range.
Touch-check or use IR thermometer to detect overheating.
Check around pump, filters, tank, connections for oil leaks.
Ensure normal operating pressure is maintained; compare with baseline.
Record and compare; clean/replace filter if pressure drop is high.
Remove dust, oil residue, debris.
Verify inspection cover and manhole lids are tight.
Add recommended oil to maintain correct level.
Ensure heater is functional and thermostat is calibrated.
Clean or replace breather elements.
Remove, calibrate, reinstall; ensure correct display.
Flush cooler tubes to prevent clogging/scaling.
Use dial/laser for alignment; re-align if necessary.
Change filter cartridges/elements as per hours/condition.
Test for water content, particulates, TAN (total acid number).
Drain old oil, clean tank, refill with fresh recommended oil.
Open up for inspection and cleaning for sludge, varnish or blockages.
Inspect for corrosion, scaling; perform cleaning or tube replacement as needed.
Trace fault/failure (e.g., pressure loss, oil contamination, pump failure).
Replace pumps, motors, heaters, filters, etc. as necessary.
Commission repaired system, check for leaks, run monitored start-up.
Listen for unusual sounds; check for vibration during operation.
Ensure normal flow; inspect sight glass; ensure supply/return is steady.
Check around bowl cover, piping, and drain for oil leaks.
Check temperature, flow, pressure, and amperage are within normal range.
Check and clean discharge path; remove accumulated sludge.
Wipe down to prevent dust/oil build-up.
Visual/mechanical check for proper alignment and fastener tightness.
Test tripping mechanisms or alarms (overspeed, overtemp).
Check lock ring and seals for wear or damage; ensure secure closure.
Inspect and clean or replace as necessary to prevent blockages.
Inspect for wear on bowl, balance if vibration is detected.
Check tension, alignment, and health; adjust or replace as needed.
Grease or oil as per OEM recommendations; listen for noise.
Check/clean contactors, relays, terminals for loose/worn parts.

column5: Perform functional test of purifying cycle
column7: Run full cycle with sampling; verify separation performance.
Remove, thoroughly clean, inspect for erosion/corrosion; replace seals/gaskets.
Verify temperature, pressure, flow sensors, controls and alarms calibration.
Check winding insulation, bearings, brushes (if any), alignment.
Open, inspect for sludge, scale, blockages; clean and reseal.
Determine cause of malfunction, repair/replace damaged part(s).
Repair/replace affected major assemblies; test after repair.
Confirm all connections, run test cycle, recheck for leaks/vibration.
